articles.headline: Tencent Bids for Gaming Empire in Deal for Developer of Clash of Clans
articles.snippet: The Chinese internet giant agreed to pay $8.6 billion agreement for a controlling stake in Supercell, a Finnish game maker.
articles.abstract: The Chinese internet giant agreed to pay $8.6 billion agreement for a controlling stake in Supercell, a Finnish game maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the world of Clash of Clans, Hou Dai has played — and paid — enough that he now leads his own clan of 50 online players.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Goodbye, Password. Banks Opt to Scan Fingers and Faces Instead.
articles.snippet: Frustrated by thieves stealing personal data from millions of customers, banks are investing in biometric technology to offer better security.
articles.abstract: Frustrated by thieves stealing personal data from millions of customers, banks are investing in biometric technology to offer better security.
articles.lead_paragraph: The banking password may be about to expire — forever.

articles.headline: In ‘Brexit’ Vote, David Cameron Faces Problem of His Own Making
articles.snippet: The British leader promised an in-or-out referendum on the European Union to solve a short-term political problem. The consequences could be enormous.
articles.abstract: The British leader promised an in-or-out referendum on the European Union to solve a short-term political problem. The consequences could be enormous.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Cameron, the British prime minister, has no one to blame but himself.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: How Do You Stop a Future Terrorist When the Only Evidence Is a Thought?
articles.snippet: The authorities are trying to reckon with attackers whose names had surfaced in terrorism investigations but who had crossed no legal boundary.
articles.abstract: The authorities are trying to reckon with attackers whose names had surfaced in terrorism investigations but who had crossed no legal boundary.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAGNANVILLE, France — The first time Larossi Abballa appeared on the radar of French terrorism investigators, the only act of violence they could pin on him was killing bunnies.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Aims to Shore Up SolarCity by Having Tesla Buy It
articles.snippet: The entrepreneur argues a “sustainable energy company” comprising the two ventures makes sense, but investors may take some convincing.
articles.abstract: The entrepreneur argues a “sustainable energy company” comprising the two ventures makes sense, but investors may take some convincing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has built an ambitious business empire on three pillars: electric cars, solar energy and space travel.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Orlando Massacre Inspires Some to Come Out as Gay
articles.snippet: Some victims of the shooting had their sexuality revealed accidentally. But for some, the massacre spurred coming out. “I just had to let them know,” said one 19-year-old who told his parents.
articles.abstract: Some victims of the shooting had their sexuality revealed accidentally. But for some, the massacre spurred coming out. “I just had to let them know,” said one 19-year-old who told his parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Just hours after the music at the Pulse nightclub was interrupted by the roar of gunfire, a teenager with a nose stud and tight jeans peered across his dinner table here. “Dad,” Carvin Casillas said, “I’m kind of gay.”

articles.headline: Anton Yelchin’s Death Highlights a Known Issue With Jeeps
articles.snippet: The Jeep model involved in the death of the actor over the weekend has had a gearshift problem previously identified by federal regulators.
articles.abstract: The Jeep model involved in the death of the actor over the weekend has had a gearshift problem previously identified by federal regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death of the actor Anton Yelchin, killed when his Jeep Grand Cherokee rolled backward down a driveway and crushed him against a mailbox pillar last weekend, has cast a public spotlight on a problem with some models of Jeeps and other Fiat Chrysler vehicles.

articles.headline: Tripping Down a Virtual Reality Rabbit Hole
articles.snippet: V.R. is at this point an experience best left for the privacy of one’s cave — a sometimes antisocial affair that does not allow for the modern world’s easy interplay of the real and the digital.
articles.abstract: V.R. is at this point an experience best left for the privacy of one’s cave — a sometimes antisocial affair that does not allow for the modern world’s easy interplay of the real and the digital.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is going to sound like the tech-nerd version of one of those first-person People magazine essays about surviving adversity: You don’t appreciate how much you need to see your hands until you can’t.
